title: Introduction to Otorhinolaryngology and Communication Sciences
requirements: For student in MPhil-PhD Otorhinolaryngology and Communication Sciences
description: This course aims to introduce a range of basic topics related to otorhinolaryngology and communication sciences. Students will gain understanding of the epidemiological and clinical issues of various otorhinolaryngology, head and neck and communication-related diseases and disorders.

title: Human Communication & Speech-Language-Hearing Sciences
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Otorhinolaryngology and Communication Sciences
description: Communication chain is a model incorporating the essential characteristics of behavioral and medical models to describe the processes involved in human communication. Stages within the communication chain includes prelinguistic, language decoding, motor programming, motor execution, transmission, reception, perception, language decoding and message interpretation. This course aims at introducing each stage in relation to the anatomical structures, neurological function, physiological function and the resultant behaviors. Breakdown in any stage leading to various disorders relating to speech, language or hearing will be described. Clinical data will be used as case studies for illustrations. In addition, mechanisms of swallowing and dysphagia will be covered.
outcome: Students will be able to achieve the following through readings, lectures, team discussions and group work.  Describe the communication chain from the perspectives of medical, linguistic and behavior models  Identify the various processes leading to a successful human communication  Explain how the breakdown in specific processes will lead to different communication disorders Describe the communication/language and speech characteristics of individuals with different communication disorders Identify the phases of normal swallowing and major causes leading to dysphagia

title: Applications of Psychology in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Otorhinolaryngology and Communication Sciences
description: The speech, language, and hearing sciences are often described as inter-disciplinary subjects, which are partly related to psychology. This course aims at giving an overview of psychology, as a systematic and scientific study of behaviours and mental processes, from the perspectives of the speech, language, and hearing sciences. The applications of psychology, including the role of mental functions in individual and social behaviour, the physiological and biological processes underlying cognitive functions and behaviours, will be introduced in the context of communication disorders and sciences.
outcome: To describe connections between knowledge gained in psychology to everyday life in the context of speech, language, and hearing sciences. To become familiar with the commonly used ways of pursuing questions in psychology as well as communication disorders and sciences, through discussion of theory, empirical research, and case applications. To continually reflect on the application of knowledge in cases and real-life situations. To integrate collaborative and holistic viewpoints into reasoning. To demonstrate professional attitude. To develop, contribute to, and maintain professional and team based relationships in in-class discussion contexts.

title: Special Topics in Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery and Communication Sciences I
requirements: For student in MPhil-PhD Otorhinolaryngology and Communication Sciences
description: This course will focus on specific topics and advanced issues related to otorhinolaryngology, head and neck surgery and communication sciences. These topics will reflect academic needs/interests, faculty expertise and student’s needs. Students are allowed to take this course more than once, and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take the course under the same topic twice.
outcome: To demonstrate abilities of informing oneself in depth about a specific field of knowledge relevant to the research project, as well as integrating and interpreting information in planning and implementing the research project.
